entry.title: Build Shipment Creation and Tracking Skill using Joule Studio integrated with SAP BN4L GTT
entry.content:
As we know by now, Joule is SAP‚Äôs generative AI copilot that helps users interact with business data and processes in a conversational, natural language format. With Joule Studio, developers and business users alike can create custom Joule skills to address specific business scenarios, extending the power of SAP Business AI.

With the latest launch of Joule Studio, we can now build custom AI agents and skills that automate workflows and improve efficiency in executing routine tasks. Joule Studio is currently live with the Skill builder and the Agent Builder is slated to be GA later this year. 

Earlier this year, I had the privilege to work with the Joule Studio product teams to build and test Logistics Agents for providing transportation options, fetching weather forecasts on transportation routes and tracking with carriers in real-time.

In this article, we will walk through the steps on how to build Joule Skills for Logistics and Transportation use cases using Joule Studio. These custom skills will help users create a shipment directly in SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) and subsequently track that shipment‚Äôs status using Global Track and Trace (GTT) using the Joule digital assistant.

This is particularly useful for transportation planners, customer service reps, and warehouse operators who want a quick and intelligent way to interact with shipment data in natural language - without navigating through multiple systems. Furthermore, once the Joule is activated in S/4HANA systems or SAP Build Workzone then Joule can create shipments directly in BN4L GTT using the data from ERP orders/deliveries. 

Step 1: Prerequisites

Before building the skill in Joule Studio, ensure you have activated the following:

  • Joule Studio on your SAP BTP subaccount. (refer provisioning Joule Studio)

  • SAP Business Network for Logistics tenant with API access. 

  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub to reference GTT APIs. 

  • Authentication credentials for SAP BN4L API endpoints. 

  • Developer role and permissions to create skills in Joule Studio.   

 

Step 2: Design the Skill in Joule Studio

Login to your SAP Build lobby to create a Joule Skill. 

Skill to Create Shipment in BN4L GTT

Step 1: Create a new Joule skill and provide a valid description which will help as the trigger mechanism. Add input parameters to the skills to capture Source Location, Destination Location, Pickup Date, Shipment No, etc. 

We can even make this optimizer this step further by fetching an ERP delivery data from a S/4HANA System using the Odata Service. With that Joule will be able to fetch the delivery details to create a shipment. However, to understand how the conversations work, we can proceed with capturing data from the user.  

Step 2: Create and Publish a Build Action from Build Lobby to integrate your BN4L GTT tenant with SAP Build. 
Here, we can use the GTT Write Service API (Shipment Event) which creates a shipment in GTT (For more info visit SAP Help)

Step 3: Add the published Action to Joule Skill and map the Skill input to Action input. 

Step 4 (Optional): Add Send Message function to display a successful shipment creation message to the User along with a hyperlink to navigate GTT shipment to v. 

Step 5: Deploy and Test the Joule Skill using the Build Environments. Currently, Joule Studio supports testing the custom Joule Skills only from within an Environment. Under Joule, launch the standalone Joule Digital Assistant. 

 

Step 3: Joule digital assistant (the conversation part) 

Use Joule digital assistant to test the skill that we just deployed. Open the logs to review the steps performed by Joule to execute a Skill based on user input. 

Create a shipment conversation with basic shipment information. 

 

Skill to Track Shipment using BN4L GTT

Step 1:  Return to SAP Build Lobby and open your project, within the project create a new Joule Skill. Remember to add a wholesome description. Add input - trackingId and output parameters -status, city, region. 

Step 2: Add a new Build Action to fetch shipment status from GTT. To find more details of the GTT Read services in the BN4L GTT Reference Guide.

Release and Publish the Action to be used in Joule Skill. 

Refer to the SAP BPA help to learn more on how to use $filter capability while querying using an Odata service. 

Step 3: Add this Action as a step function in the Track Shipment Joule Skill. Map the Action input to the Skills Input to pass the tracking number from the user as a query parameter to the GTT read service. This will improve the overall performance and response time of Joule during runtime conversations. 

Create a new destination variable to represent the GET service BTP destination. 

Step 4: In the End step, map the Skills Output to the corresponding fields from the Action Output result. This will enable Joule to form a logical output based on the message to be displayed to the user.  

Step 5:  Release and deploy the skill to the same Environment created for the first skill. 

Step 6: Navigate to the Environment, now you should be able to see the latest version of the Project deployed. Launch the Joule DA from the Joule tab. 

Step 3: Joule digital assistant (the conversation part) 

Track the shipment with Shipment ID to view the execution status and the current location. 

Step 4: Integrate Joule with SAP Build Workzone

Enable your users to interact with Joule and enjoy these custom skills by activating Joule in SAP Build Workzone.  

Final Thoughts

This is an high level overview on building custom Joule Skills for deterministic tasks based on business processes expanding the horizon of SAP Business AI. With Joule Studio, we are now able to extend SAP Joule's AI capabilities to address unique business needs. 

Learn more about how SAP Premium Engagement can help you accelerate your digital transformation with curated AI workshops and discovery sessions. 

SAP Business AI Joule SAP Business Network for Logistics SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition @SAPMaxAttention

entry.title: Exploring AI and next-gen Cloud ERP innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
The 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is out and this product blog by @BeSchulze give a great overview of the key innovation. With this update, SAP continues to push the boundaries of enterprise automation and intelligence. With the latest innovations powered by generative AI, customers benefit from improved transparency, faster decision-making, and simpler day-to-day operations. From financial consolidation to payment analysis and sustainability reporting, these updates bring intelligent capabilities directly into the flow of business. 

This video is very special as you will meet my new Synthesia avatar, who will give you a summary of the key "AI"-led innovations for this release. By the way, what do you think about this avatar? Let me know in the comments. 

 

Group Reporting: AI-assisted business insights for group financial statements review booklet

Building on the successful beta release in 2502, predefined AI-assisted business insights‚Äîalso known as quick actions‚Äîare now generally available in the Group Financial Statements Review Booklet. These insights help streamline financial review processes by highlighting key figures, variances, and relevant context in natural language.

The Group Financial Statements Review Booklet, Cost Centers Review Booklet, and Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services now all include AI-powered business insights that enable faster analysis and easier interpretation of financial data. By reducing manual analysis effort and surfacing relevant context automatically, these booklets drive efficiency across various reporting tasks.

Figure 1: AI-assisted financial business insights

 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, AI-assisted payment exception analysis

In the Manage Automatic Payments app (App ID: F0770), a new AI capability enhances the process of analyzing payment exceptions after a payment proposal run. This feature not only provides natural language explanations of payment exceptions but also highlights relevant log entries and suggests resolution actions.

This innovation reduces the time spent investigating and resolving issues in payment proposals. By guiding users directly to the root cause and recommended next steps, the process becomes significantly more efficient‚Äîimproving payment accuracy and minimizing delays in financial operations.

Figure 2: AI-assisted payment exception analysis

 

Figure 3: Digital Library - AI-Assisted Features

 

Enabling automatic allocations of carbon quantities by reflecting allocations in financial accounting

With growing importance on sustainable business practices, the 2508 release introduces automatic allocation of carbon quantities aligned with financial accounting data. This feature retrieves financial flow data from the connected system and automatically calculates account assignments, target accounts, and allocation ratios.

No manual calculation of receiver percentages is needed‚Äîcarbon data is allocated consistently based on monetary values. This ensures alignment between sustainability and financial reporting, offering more precise reflection of operational impact and enabling integrated performance tracking across both domains.

Figure 4: Manage Allocations ‚Äì Create from Financial Flow

 

Figure 5: Automatic allocation of carbon quantities

 

Unlock seamless data access with AI-assisted easy enterprise search 

Accessing business data is now even more intuitive with the AI-assisted easy enterprise search, which allows users to search using natural language. Instead of navigating through complex structures, a simple query like ‚ÄúShow me sales orders overall status in process‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow me open sales orders that have a net value greater than 100 EUR‚Äù provides relevant results instantly.

The system adapts the search results based on the user‚Äôs role, ensuring that only the most relevant business objects are presented. This not only improves search accuracy but also accelerates insight extraction‚Äîmaking it easier to act quickly and confidently in a data-rich environment. To enable this feature, select the 'enable AI natural language search' checkbox in the user profile settings.

 

Currently in beta testing: AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications 

Personalizing the My Home workspace becomes faster and smarter with the new AI-assisted smart personalization feature. Currently in beta testing, it allows users to tailor their applications and insight tiles using natural language.

Applications can be added in just two clicks, including a preview to confirm suitability. This streamlines customization, especially for new or infrequent users, by offering AI-powered suggestions, application descriptions, and live KPIs for dynamic tiles. The experience is intuitive and efficient, ensuring that personalization aligns with users‚Äô daily workflows.

Interested in experiencing these improvements first-hand? Join the SAP beta testing for the latest AI-assisted features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and contribute to shaping future developments. For more information, see: Get Involved Early, and register today to help drive the evolution of AI advancements. 

 

Currently in beta testing: AI-assisted easy fill 

Also in beta, AI-assisted easy fill reimagines how form fields are completed. Instead of manually searching for and filling out fields, users can enter data via natural language. The system intelligently matches input to the correct fields and provides a clear overview before confirmation.

This innovation saves time, reduces navigation complexity, and increases accuracy in form completion. With automatic field matching and editable previews, easy fill offers a new level of convenience for maintaining business objects efficiently.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 delivers a powerful set of innovations that bridge insight and action with the support of generative AI. Whether it's optimizing financial processes, enhancing personalization, or improving sustainability reporting, these features demonstrate SAP‚Äôs commitment to building a truly intelligent cloud ERP system.

Interested in experiencing this enhanced feature?‚ÄØJoin the SAP beta testing for the latest AI-assisted features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and contribute to shaping future developments. For more information, see: Get Involved Early, and register today to help drive the evolution of AI advancements. 

We‚Äôre also pleased to share that three recently introduced AI-assisted user experience innovations‚Äîenterprise search,easy filter,and smart summarization‚Äîare now available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition at no additional cost. To get started, simply accept the SAP AI Terms. Once completed, we‚Äôll reach out to enable these capabilities on your tenants, so you can immediately begin benefiting from more intuitive interactions, faster insights, and enhanced productivity.

 

Joule for Business

With this release, Joule for Business brings a new dimension of intelligent assistance to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, enabling business users to interact with their systems through natural language while achieving impactful outcomes faster.

Figure 6: SAP Joule for Business

By embedding artificial intelligence directly into the system, Joule acts as a digital assistant that transforms how users navigate and operate business applications. It removes technical barriers by interpreting user intent and delivering contextually relevant results, all through intuitive, conversational interaction.

 

Simplifying service contract management

Joule for Business makes managing service contracts more seamless than ever. Users can describe their needs in natural language‚Äîfor example, ‚Äúshow me my upcoming expiring service contracts‚Äù‚Äîand Joule provides direct access to the relevant apps such as Manage Service Contracts, Service Management Overview, and the Service Contracts Dashboard.

Figure 7: Navigational assistance to service contract management applications through Joule

From reviewing performance to processing contracts at scale, apps like Mass Processing of Service Contracts and Monitor Auto Renewal Logs become instantly accessible. This intuitive guidance enhances user satisfaction, shortens time to action, and significantly increases efficiency in service contract workflows.

 

Streamlining solution order management

For managing solution orders, Joule transforms user interaction into a results-driven experience. Whether the need is to assess order profitability or track fulfillment progress, users simply express what they want in natural language. Joule interprets the request and navigates directly to apps like Solution Orders Overview or Solution Order Profitability.

Figure 8: Navigational assistance to solution order management applications through Joule

This saves time, reduces manual steps, and lets users focus on driving outcomes rather than figuring out system navigation. Joule ensures that the most relevant tools are just a prompt away, transforming how users approach solution order management.

 

AI-Assisted sales order status check

In sales operations, timely status checks are critical. Joule for Business introduces an AI-powered capability to check the status of sales orders and flag any fulfillment issues. Instead of scanning through data manually, users can now ask questions like ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs blocking the delivery of my sales order?‚Äù

Joule responds with natural language explanations of current statuses, highlights potential delays or issues, and offers resolution suggestions. It also provides direct access to relevant applications for follow-up actions‚Äîaccelerating resolution and improving transparency in the sales process.

Figure 9: Joule AI-assisted sales order status check

Joule for Business continues to evolve as a powerful ally for business users, combining the strength of generative AI with SAP‚Äôs enterprise-grade reliability to make every interaction faster, smarter, and more human-centered.

 

Joule base entitlement and Cloud ERP Base AI entitlement

With Joule Base Entitlement in the SAP Store, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers can consume all of our Joule features in 2508 release for free. 

With SAP Cloud ERP Base AI Entitlement here, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers  can consume Easy Filter, Smart Summarization and Enterprise Search for free. 

 

Shaping the future of intelligent ERP - together

As AI continues to evolve, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition remains at the forefront‚Äîembedding intelligence directly into business processes to drive clarity, speed, and efficiency. With the 2508 release, generative AI is not just enhancing isolated tasks; it's transforming how work gets done across finance, sustainability, and user experience. Whether it‚Äôs simplifying complex reviews, automating routine actions, or making data more accessible, these innovations reflect a new standard for intelligent ERP.

We‚Äôre excited to continue this journey and invite you to explore these capabilities firsthand. Join our beta programs, share your feedback, and help shape the future of AI in the cloud. The momentum is strong‚Äîand this is only the beginning.

 

üìΩÔ∏è Watch the replays of our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Early Release Series!

From July 21 to July 25, we hosted a series of 21 compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find the recording and presentation for all presentations. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand‚Äìanywhere, anytime.

üîéFind all our assets

We at Cloud ERP Product Success offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you below:

entry.title: Using Jupyter in SAP Business Application Studio ‚Äì my notes
entry.content:
In my previous blog post Using Python in SAP Business Application Studio ‚Äì my notes, I focused on Python.

This blog post focuses on running Jupyter notebooks in SAP Business Application Studio (referred to as "BAS" below). I assume you're not an absolute beginner with SAP Business Application Studio‚Äîor at least you're familiar with Visual Studio Code. If you need a general introduction to navigating, coding, and executing code in notebooks using the Jupyter extension, then check: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/datascience/jupyter-notebooks#_create-or-open-a-jupyter-notebook 

For the examples in this post, I‚Äôll be using the SAP Business Application Studio, which is available in the SAP BTP Trial environment.

Creating a virtual environment with the Python extension

As already discussed in Persisting Python environment when using Jupyter notebooks in SAP Business Application Studio, one of the first things you might want to do, when working with the Python code in BAS, is to create a virtual environment. There, we discussed how to use the `python -m venv` command to create it. Now, let's use the extension commands.

ü§ì Pro tip: if you want to understand what is happening when extension commands are executed, then:

  1. Open the Output panel (eg, View -> Output from the menu).
  2. Choose the output for the Python extension, and then in Settings, set the level to Info and Set As Default:

     

  3. Alternatively, if the Python extension has not yet been loaded, then open the command palette and run the command >Python: Show Output:

Go to the command palette and run the command `Python: Create Environment...`...

..and select the Venv option to create a virtual environment `.venv` (the name cannot be modified, at least in the current version of the Python extension):

...selecting the required base Python run-time installation (like ~/.asdf-inst/shims/pythonüòû

If you have set output on the Info level for the Python extension, then you should see (interesting) details on how the environment was created:

One additional note: the .gitignore file has been automatically created for the virtual environment:

Select the Jupyter kernel

To execute code in your Jupyter notebook, you need to select a Jupyter kernel that will be used to execute the code.

Click Select Kernel and then on Python Environments... category:

...which will show you the list of Python environments that the Python extension found in your BAS dev space. Click on your virtual environment created for your project, like .venv:

Execute code in a Jupyter notebook

During the first execution of your code, Jupyter will check if the IPython Kernel executable (the Python package ipykernel) is installed in the selected Python environment. If not, it will automatically install it, as can be seen in the Jupyter extension's output, and then start it:

Once started, the Kernel exposes 5 ports for communication with your notebook, which can be seen in the run-time specification in a file ~/.local/share/jupyter/runtime/kernel-*.json. While this information should not be required in most of the basic scenarios, you might find it overwhelming that BAS displays pop-up messages for each port every time the kernel runtime starts:

While information about open ports is relevant when developing front-end applications using SAP Business Application Studio, it might be useless and overwhelming when working with Jupyter notebooks. So, click on the settings icon and turn off notifications from the "Exposing router ports" extension or disable this extension completely:

Limiting listed Python environments

You might also find it quite overwhelming to deal with the list of all the global Python locations when setting the kernel for a notebook. To reduce this list, select the command Jupyter: Filter Kernels from the command palette:

...which opens the setting jupyter.kernels.excludePythonEnvironments. Switch to the Workspace tab and click Add Item to specify which Python environments to exclude from the list. You might want to add the following items to the list:

/bin/python3
/usr/bin/python3
~/.asdf-inst/shims/python3.13
~/.asdf-inst/shims/python3
~/.asdf-inst/shims/python

ü§ìPro tip: these values can also be edited in the project's file .vscode/settings.json.

{
    "jupyter.kernels.excludePythonEnvironments": [
        "/bin/python3",
        "/usr/bin/python3",
        "~/.asdf-inst/shims/python3.13",
        "~/.asdf-inst/shims/python3",
        "~/.asdf-inst/shims/python"
    ]
}

Next time you need to pick the kernel for a Jupyter notebook, you should see only your project's virtual Python environment:

You should be ready to work with your Jupyter notebooks in SAP Business Application Studio!

Please share your tips in the comments!

------

-Vitaliy, aka @Sygyzmundovych

entry.title: Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
The 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition contains enhancements to popular AI features and new natural language interaction options that help you work more intelligently and intuitively.

We‚Äôve spent the past 6 months since the 2502 release working with your feedback ‚Äì from beta programs, to roundtable discussions in the Public Cloud Practitioner Forum, to one-on-one meetings with customers ‚Äì to learn how we can help you achieve more with the help of AI in your system. Let‚Äôs take a look at what‚Äôs new, update you on the commercialization of some features, and give you resources for getting involved with our upcoming beta program. 

Natural language filtering now supports a wider range of queries

The AI-assisted easy filter (first released in 2502) enables you to filter list reports in your SAP Fiori elements-based apps using natural language. This simplifies how you access the information you need and reduces the training time required to pick up new applications delivered by SAP.

AI-assisted easy filter enables natural language filtering of pages with lists of business objects. Here the user can filter for a given sold-to party using plain language rather than needing to know its key..

For 2508, we‚Äôve made a number of enhancements to make interactions with AI-assisted easy filter even more intuitive:

  1. Tables can be filtered without needing to know an object‚Äôs specific key. Instead, simply enter the name of the object you are looking for. The AI-assisted easy filter will map that text to the intended key and apply it to the filter fields for you, which is a much more natural way to search for information. In the event that there are multiple keys with similar names, you will receive results filtered for those names. As before, you can always refine your results in the input field or using the classic filtering.
  2. We‚Äôve also worked to ensure parity between the filter fields that can be applied using the AI-assisted easy filter and the classic filter bar. Some users had reported that, in some cases, AI-assisted easy filter would not apply queries to certain filters. This was caused by the fact that some of the filter fields used navigation paths to different entities instead of the main entity for the app. This scenario is now supported and you can filter on any property present in the classic filter bar.

My Home Personalization with Insights Cards supports more apps and a new way to query for cards

The ability to create Insights cards and quickly add them to My Home now supports 20 SAP Fiori apps.

AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for Insights cards was released as a Joule capability as part of its 2503 release. The functionality allows end users to query Joule for business data they regularly need using natural language. The output is displayed as a card that can be added to their My Home page for easy reference. This makes it easier for users to access information they need to make everyday business decisions and move processes forward.

This functionality was initially limited to 9 applications. With the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, this coverage has been extended to 11 additional applications. This gives users easier and wider access to the business data that is important to them. AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for Insights cards now supports the following applications:

  1. Find Maintenance Order
  2. Find Maintenance Order and Operation
  3. Maintain Bill Of Material
  4. Manage Business Partner Master Data
  5. Manage Customer Returns
  6. Manage Manual Reservations
  7. Manage Material Coverage (Version 2)
  8. Manage Outbound Deliveries
  9. Manage Product Master Data
  10. Manage Purchase Orders (Version 2)
  11. Manage Purchase Requisitions - Professional
  12. Manage Sales Orders
  13. Manage Sales Orders - Version 2
  14. Manage Sales Quotation - Version 2
  15. Manage Supplier Master Data
  16. Manage Usage Decisions
  17. Material Documents Overview
  18. Project Control - Enterprise Projects
  19. Reproceess Failed Material Movements
  20. Supplier Invoices List (Version 2)

Users can now use natural language to create and add Insights Cards directly in My Home.

For the 2508 release, we have also introduced a new way to create Insights cards using natural language: you can access the feature directly from My Home. This gives users the flexibility to choose the personalization option that works best for them, giving them access to the information they need at a glance.

If you'd like to read even more exciting updates about features and functionality included in the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, check out the following fantastic blogs from my colleagues:

  • For a general overview of new functionality: Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release 
  • For a few more AI uses cases, some focused on particular business processes: Exploring AI and next-gen Cloud ERP innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 

Commercialization update: New Base AI includes common AI functions at no additional cost

For the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, a number of AI solutions have been added to its Base AI offering. This means that you can use the features absolutely free of charge. You simply need to sign the SAP AI terms here and SAP will handle the activation for you.

Included in the Base AI offering for this release are AI-assisted easy filter and AI-assisted smart summarization, as well as AI-assisted enterprise search (which allows you to look up data from the search in My Home). Give them a try!

Try out upcoming AI innovations in the 2508 beta

For customers looking to try out the absolute latest in AI innovations, registration for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition beta is still open. This is your opportunity to try out and give feedback on new use cases for AI in your system. The solutions up for beta testing are free to use for the duration of the program.  Below is a preview of some of the features that will be available. Please note: Customer/partner participation will be at the discretion of the Beta Testing Program team. Participants must use SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition productively. Future developments are at the discretion of SAP and their details and delivery dates may be changed at any time.

Resolve situations directly in My Home without navigating to applications

AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home allows you to quickly take action on business processes that need your attention directly in My Home..

The Situations tab in My Home provides quick summaries of business processes that need to be addressed in your system. Previously, this meant reading the alert on the tile, navigating to the required app(s), and making the required changes. With AI-assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home, we‚Äôre streamlining how you take action on these scenarios. You‚Äôll now be able to see a summary of the situation, start the relevant business process from quick actions on the card, and even make changes to the business data all without leaving your My Home page. This allows you to stay on top of your business and resolve potential issues even faster.

Streamline data entry in object pages

AI-assisted easy fill streamlines data entry by populating object pages based on natural language input (for example: emails or messages from colleagues).

Depending on your business scenario, SAP Fiori object pages can sometimes be quite complex. Data entry might mean filling a field at the top of the screen, scrolling for several sections to add more information, and so on. AI-assisted easy fill enables you to enter your updates into a single field using natural language. The solution then maps your input to the proper fields, highlights any potential inconsistencies that may need to be addressed, and ‚Äì after your review ‚Äì updates the fields. This will help speed up data entry and reduce training time for new users.

Resolve error messages with AI assistance

AI-assisted error explanation provides resolution recommendations to error and warning messages in your system.

Learning new business processes can be tricky. AI-assisted error explanation uses AI to generate explanations and suggest resolutions for errors that are triggered in your system. This streamlines how you handle errors and reduces training time, making you more productive and helping you pick up processes even faster; in addition to reducing your organization‚Äôs support load.

Search for applications you need using natural language

AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications allows you to search for applications using natural language.

When learning a new business process or stepping into a new role, it can sometimes be challenging to find the exact application you need to carry out a task. With AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications, you can search for the app you need using natural language. Simply type in what you need to do and get served the required application, which you can add to your My Home page with a single click. This allows you to access the applications you need without needing to know the exact application name.

We want to hear from you!

Whether you take advantage of the new free features in the Base AI package, subscribe to cutting edge technologies, or choose to take part in a beta program; we want to hear what you think about these solutions! Give them a try and share your feedback below or with the product team. Your experience is critical to understanding how we can make these innovations even better for you.

When you‚Äôre ready to get involved, you can:

  1. Register to use base AI features
  2. Sign up for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition beta
  3. Join the Public Cloud Practitioner Forum (for customers live on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

Happy experimenting! We‚Äôll be back with another update for the 2602 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

entry.title: Using conda-forge in SAP Business Application Studio ‚Äì my notes
entry.content:
In my previous blog posts, I focused on Using Python in SAP Business Application Studio and Using Jupyter in SAP Business Application Studio with Python's virtual environments. But SAP Business Application Studio (referred to as "BAS" below) also allows you to work with the Conda environments:

Usually, Conda is used when one needs binary package management, and installation with pip fails because of the build requirements that cannot be successfully completed with the tools and authorizations a developer has in their BAS dev space.

üëâ At the time of writing this post, using Conda might require additional commercial licenses from Anaconda, Inc. if downloading their tools and/or packages from their `default` channel. This might be a valid case for you, but this blog post covers only the use of the community-driven `conda-forge` channel and the minimum tools required to use it. To the best of my knowledge, I discuss only the technical setup here, but you might need to check any license implications for the dependencies of a project you are working on.

Install miniforge

Miniforge is a minimal installer for Conda and Mamba with the conda-forge channel set as the default (and only) channel.

Follow the installation steps, for example from https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge?tab=readme-ov-file#unix-like-platforms-macos-linux--wsl

Download and run the installation script.

curl --location --remote-name --output-dir ~/tmp "https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge/releases/latest/download/Miniforge3-$(uname)-$(uname -m).sh"

bash ~/tmp/Miniforge3-$(uname)-$(uname -m).sh -b

 Configure conda

Activate conda and its base environment.

eval "$(/home/user/miniforge3/bin/conda shell.$(basename "${SHELL}") hook)"

 Initialize conda (it will add the shell's integration).

conda init

To prevent the conda's base environment from being activated on startup (because it will be taken care of by the Python extension), run the following command:

conda config --set auto_activate_base false

For changes to take effect, close and re-open your current shell.

Update conda's base environment to the latest packages from the community-maintained conda-forge channel.

conda update -n base --all --yes

You can also use the faster mamba command instead of conda. Both are parts of the Miniforge installation.

Point Python extension to your Conda executable

In Terminal, check the location of the conda command, which should be something like /home/user/miniforge3/condabin/conda:

which conda

 In Settings, open python.condaPath and switch to the Remote tab. Input the value.

Create a .conda environment in your project

Open your project folder in BAS.

From the command palette, start the command Python: Create Environment..., then Conda environment type...

...and select the required Python version from the list:

You should see the message that the environment is created and set as the active one for the project.

Open a new Terminal session, and you should see the .conda environment set.

You can check the list of environments with the command:

conda env list

Install IPyKernel in your .conda environment

Unlike in a "venv" virtual environment, the Python extension might not automatically install IPyKernel in a conda environment. You need to install it manually.

In Terminal, with the .conda environment set in the command line, run the command:

conda install ipykernel --yes

Check with the command

conda list ipykernel

Select the .conda env in your notebook

Now, you can open your project's Jupyter notebook, select the .conda environment, and execute the code ü§ì

You should be ready to work with conda-forge in SAP Business Application Studio now! 

Please share your tips in the comments!

In my other blog posts, I focused on:
üêçUsing Python in SAP Business Application Studio, and
ü™ê Using Jupyter in SAP Business Application Studio.

------

-Vitaliy, aka @Sygyzmundovych

entry.title: Leveraging SAP Joule for Performance & Goals Management: Exact Prompts for Maximum Productivity
entry.content:
SAP Joule, the generative AI assistant built into SAP SuccessFactors, is transforming how organizations manage Performance & Goals (PMGM) activities. With Joule‚Äôs natural language interface, managers and employees can interact directly with their performance data. Driving speed, accuracy, and engagement. Here‚Äôs how you can make the most of Joule, with concrete prompts you can use right away.

 

1. What Can Joule Do for PMGM?

Joule bridges the gap between traditional HR processes and user-friendly digital experiences, empowering you to:

  • Access and update goals

  • Navigate and complete performance reviews

  • Give and receive feedback in real time

  • Manage team calibration, analytics, and more

2. Try These Exact Prompts With Joule

Below are ready-to-use prompts you can enter right into Joule to access, update, or analyze PMGM data:

Goal Management

  • ‚ÄúShow me all my current performance goals.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúUpdate the status of my goal ‚ÄòIncrease Q3 Sales‚Äô to 80% complete.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúAdd a comment to my goal ‚ÄòImprove customer satisfaction‚Äô: ‚ÄòCompleted training on new CRM.‚Äô‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúList my team‚Äôs goals for this quarter.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúHelp me cascade my goal ‚ÄòLaunch New Product‚Äô to my direct reports.‚Äù

Performance Reviews & 360 Feedback

  • ‚ÄúOpen my performance review form.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúWhat is the status of my 360 review?‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúShow me feedback I‚Äôve received in my performance review.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúWho on my team hasn‚Äôt submitted their performance reviews yet?‚Äù

Continuous Performance Activities

  • ‚ÄúCreate a new activity: ‚ÄòCompleted lead generation workshop.‚Äô‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúAdd an achievement for ‚ÄòClosed major client deal‚Äô to my performance record.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúView all feedback I‚Äôve given this year.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúRequest feedback from John Smith on my collaboration skills.‚Äù

Team Management & Calibration

  • ‚ÄúShow me my team‚Äôs performance ratings distribution.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúList employees in my team who are ready for promotion.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúStart a talent calibration session for my department.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúGenerate a summary report of my team‚Äôs goals progress.‚Äù

Analytics & Insights

  • ‚ÄúShow me a dashboard of team goal completion rates.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúWhat percentage of my team met their goals last cycle?‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúGive me insights on performance trends over the past year.‚Äù

Other Practical Prompts

  • ‚ÄúRemind me to submit my self-appraisal by Friday.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúExplain the 9-box grid to me.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúHelp me find the company‚Äôs goal library.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúHow do I assign a new goal to my direct report?‚Äù

3. Best Practices to Drive Value

  • Encourage managers and employees to experiment with these prompts for day-to-day PMGM tasks.

  • Incorporate common prompts in onboarding or training materials to boost adoption.

  • Use prompts to keep review cycles on track with reminders and reporting.

  • Harness dashboard and analytics prompts for sharper, data-driven decisions.

4. The Big Payoff

Using SAP Joule with the right prompts brings:

  • Immediate access to the right performance data and actions

  • Consistency and transparency in performance management

  • Engaged, self-sufficient managers and employees

  • More productive, agile, and collaborative talent processes

Try out these prompts in Joule today and unlock a new era of intelligent, conversational performance management in your organization!

entry.title: ChatGPT Meets SAP Analytics Cloud: A Developer‚Äôs Guide to ChatGPT Custom Widget
entry.content:
SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is a powerful platform for data analytics, planning, and predictive insights. Enhancing SAC with AI-driven conversational capabilities can significantly improve user interaction and data exploration. The ChatGPT Custom Widget for SAC enables seamless integration of OpenAI's ChatGPT chat box directly into your SAC stories and analytic applications, providing a flexible, fast, and customizable chat interface. This blog walks you through the features, installation, and usage of the ChatGPT Custom Widget, empowering you to leverage AI-powered conversational analytics within SAP Analytics Cloud.

 

What is the ChatGPT Custom Widget for SAC?

The ChatGPT Custom Widget is a ready-to-use component that embeds a ChatGPT-powered chat box inside your SAC environment. It allows users to interact with data and analytics through natural language queries, enhancing the decision-making process with AI-generated insights.

üì•Download Links: ChatGPT Custom Widget: https://sap-custom-widget.rohitchouhan.com/?dl=ChatGPT
üîóGitHub Repository: https://github.com/SAP-Custom-Widget/ChatGPT
üìöDocumentation: chatgpt-custom-widget-documentation.pdf 

Key Features and Capabilities:

  • 100% Free to Use (needs OpenAI API key)
  • Modern Chat Interface: WhatsApp/Messenger-style design
  • Multiple AI Models: GPT-3.5-turbo, GPT-4, GPT-4-turbo support
  • Advanced Parameters: Temperature (0-2), max tokens (1-4096), response choices (1-10)
  • Custom Styling: Colors, fonts, sizes, themes
  • Real-time Responses: Streaming text generation
  • Export Chat:  Conversation export
  • Error Handling: Built-in API error management
  • Auto-updates: Widget version notifications
  • Mobile Responsive: Works on tablets and phones

Installation Guide

Follow these simple steps to add the ChatGPT Custom Widget to your SAP Analytics Cloud environment:

  1. Download the Widget JSON File
    Obtain the ChatGPT.json file from the official GitHub repository or the provided link.
  2. Access SAC Custom Widgets
    Log in to your SAC portal. Navigate to Stories from the left sidebar, then select the Custom Widget tab.
  3. Upload the Widget
    Click the + icon on the right side and upload the downloaded ChatGPT.json file.
  4. Ready to Use
    The widget is now available for use in your SAC stories and analytic applications.

Complete Guidance and Tutorial Video

If you want to see how to use and install what are the feature, please follow this video to know it better.

Configuration and Usage

  1. Get OpenAI API Key
    Visit platform.openai.com ‚Üí Sign up/Login ‚Üí Go to API Keys ‚Üí Create new key ‚Üí Copy and save securely
  2. Add Widget to Story
    Open your SAC story ‚Üí Insert ‚Üí Custom Widget ‚Üí Select "ChatGPT Widget" ‚Üí Drag to canvas
  3. Configure API Settings
    Designer Panel ‚Üí Builder ‚Üí API Configuration:
    • API Key: Paste your OpenAI key
    • Model: Choose gpt-3.5-turbo (fast, cheap) or gpt-4 (better quality)
    • Temperature: 0.1 (focused) to 1.5 (creative)
    • Max Tokens: 150-2048 (response length)
    • System Message: Set AI behavior and context
  4. Customize Appearance
    Design tab ‚Üí  Styles, header text
  5. Test and Deploy
    Preview mode ‚Üí Test chat functionality ‚Üí Save story ‚Üí Share with users

Advanced Use Cases and Applications

Business Intelligence Applications:

  • Data Exploration: "Show me sales trends for Q4" or "What are the top performing products?"
  • Report Generation: Auto-create executive summaries from dashboard data
  • Anomaly Detection: Ask AI to identify unusual patterns in data
  • KPI Analysis: Get explanations for metric changes and recommendations

Industry-Specific Applications:

  • Customer Service: Automate FAQ responses, provide product recommendations, handle basic inquiries
  • Sales & Marketing: Lead qualification, campaign analysis, customer segmentation insights
  • Finance: Budget variance analysis, financial report explanations, cost optimization suggestions
  • Operations: Process optimization, resource allocation, performance monitoring
  • HR Analytics: Employee satisfaction analysis, recruitment insights, performance reviews

Integrating ChatGPT with SAC transforms your analytics environment into an interactive, AI-powered assistant that enhances productivity and decision-making.

Security Considerations:

  • API Key Protection: Never share or hardcode API keys
  • Data Privacy: Be cautious with sensitive business data in prompts
  • Rate Limiting: Monitor API usage to avoid quota limits
  • Access Control: Restrict widget access to authorized users only
  • Regular Updates: Keep widget updated for security patches

Conclusion

The ChatGPT Custom Widget for SAP Analytics Cloud is a game-changer for organizations looking to infuse AI-driven conversational intelligence into their analytics workflows. With easy installation, flexible customization, and powerful OpenAI integration, this widget empowers users to interact naturally with their data and unlock deeper insights.

Get started today by downloading the widget, setting up your OpenAI API key, and embedding the chat box into your SAC stories. Experience the future of analytics with ChatGPT and SAP Analytics Cloud!

If you want to explore the widget further or contribute, check out the GitHub repository maintained by the developer Rohit Chouhan.

entry.title: Hands-on Tutorial: SAP Databricks
entry.content:
With SAP Databricks we now have a dedicated environment for Data Scientists within the SAP Business Data Cloud. This blog gives a practical introduction to this bespoke Databricks edition by implementing a bare bones demand forecast. SAP Databricks includes important functionality beyond what is explained in this entry-level tutorial., for example data sharing, experiment tracking or AutoML.

The integration of SAP Databricks is adding a new option to the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), giving customers more choice when creating custom extensions or applications. Existing components on the BTP, which you might already be familiar with, remain very relevant and strategic, such as:

  • SAP AI Core, which provides for example access to a long list of Large Language Models through its Generative AI Hub. Some of the models are even hosted on SAP's own physical infrastructure, giving increased security (currently Mistral and Aleph Alpha).
  • SAP Document AI, which extracts information from documents such as PDFs, Excel, images, ...
  • SAP HANA Cloud and SAP Datasphere, with their built-in multi-model capabilities, ie Machine Learning, embeddings generation for Text, Vector engine, Graph engine, Geospatial 
  • SAP Build, Joule Studio for adding new skills to our digital assistant Joule, and the ability to create new AI agents on the roadmap. This blog (series) on SAP's AI Agent Architecture by our CTO and Chief AI Officer Philipp Herzig gives an excellent overview of the wider picture.
  • SAP Databricks can also be used as development environment for the above components. This blog by @san_tran for instance shows a SAP Databricks project that integrates with Large Language Models on SAP AI Core. 

And remember to check on the AI/ML functionality that has already been built into SAP standard applications, or what is in the pipeline to be released. Both released and planned functionality is shown in the Roadmap Explorer.

Note: All data, code and images that are used in this blog can be downloaded from this repository: Hands-on Tutorial SAP Databricks. In that repository you find the individual files but also the whole project exported as Databricks Archive.

Before we get going, big thanks to Stojan Maleschlijski for all the great collaboration, including exploring the SAP Databricks capabilities together! @stojanm 

 

Table of contents

  • Use Case 
  • Architecture
  • Prerequisites
  • Upload data
  • Explore the data
  • Create a forecast with SAP Databricks
  • Schedule a forecast with SAP Databricks
  • Good to know
    • Base file
    • Lineage & Table usage insights
    • Visuals
  • Summary

 

Use Case

This blog aims to give a first introduction for carrying out a Machine Learning project on SAP Databricks. Trying to simulate a demand forecast, we will predict how many nights people spend in a hotel in Switzerland. We use some granular data that is kindly shared by the Swiss Statistics department.

A Data Scientist (you) creates a monthly forecast and sets up a schedule for the forecast to be updated every month.  This data would then become part of a business process, maybe you want to provide the data to business users in a dashboard. This tutorial however focusses solely on creating and scheduling the forecast in SAP Databricks.

It's a simple time-series forecasting example, but the concept is still extremely relevant for so many different business requirements. Instead of forecasting how many visitors are staying overnight, you might need to forecast your sales quantities, your cash flow or even for topics that don't come immediately to mind. One customer for instance is using time-series forecasting to improve the data quality of external data that is loaded into the system. If a new value is outside the predicted range, there might be a data quality issue and IT can follow up, whether the data is correct or whether indeed a data quality issue cropped up.

 

Architecture

In a productive system a typical architecture and data flow would look like this.

  1. A Data Product is pushed into the Business Data Cloud Object Store
  2. This Data Product is shared with SAP Databricks
  3. SAP Databricks creates and saves a forecast as DeltaTable into the Object Store
  4. This table is registered as Custom Data Product in the Business Data Cloud
  5. SAP Datasphere installs the Custom Data Product, making it accessible for further data modelling and visualisation in SAP Analytics Cloud

 

The architecture of this hands-on exercise is focused purely on getting some familiarity with SAP Databricks. The only interface we will be using is SAP Databricks. We use it to upload the data and to go through the steps of a Machine Learning project.

 

Prerequisites

Getting started is pretty easy.

  • You will just need to have access to an instance of SAP Databricks. This could be the SAP Business Data Cloud trial.
  • Some familiarity with SQL and especially Python would be very useful. 
  • And maybe just some curiosity to try something new.

 

Upload data

Start by bringing the historic data, on which we want to train a model, into the system. Upload the dataset OVERNIGHTSTAYS.csv with the Graphical User Interface of SAP Databricks. Follow the steps shown in this screencam. In case that you are working with the trial, then you need to change the Catalog drop-down as shown to "workspace".

The data is uploaded. it is showing in the Catalog as (Delta)Table. Physically it is stored in the Object Store. The table's Overview tab lists the column names and their data types:

 

Move to the table's "Sample Data" tab to see some of the uploaded rows.

The first lines shows that in January 2022 there were 392.805 nights spent by Swiss residents in the area of Graub√ºnden. In case you are not that familiar with Swiss geography, Graub√ºnden is the largest Canton in Switzerland, it's in the Alps and includes beautiful places like St. Moritz and Davos. 

 

Explore the data 

You have two options to explore the data in SAP Databricks.

  • Either query the DeltaTable directly with SQL
  • Or use a Notebook, in which you can use both SQL or Python

Data exploration with the SQL Editor

Let's look closer into the data. You can start with some SQL statements. You can go into the SQL Editor and type in your own syntax. The screencam shows two simple examples. We learn for instance that we have data from January 2022 to May 2025 to work with.

  • SELECT * from overnightstays
  • SELECT min(MONTH), max(month) from overnightstays

 

Or describe what you are looking for and have SAP Databrick's write the SQL for you! Click that small red-ish star icon to toggle on the Databricks Assistant.

 

Just try out what you are interested in. I was wondering for example:

  • which regions are in overnightstays?
  • use table overnightstays to determine how many overnight stays were they by region, sort the results
  • use table overnightstays to summarise overnightstays by countryofresidence

 

It turns out that most overnight stays in Switzerland are by Swiss residents, followed by German residents. Maybe surprisingly residents from the United States are a close third.

 

Data exploration with a Notebook

Now continue the data exploration in a Notebook. Databricks Notebooks are quite special in that they can contain more than one scripting language. SAP Databricks supports both SQL as well as Python. The Notebook created in this section can also be downloaded from the repository.

Begin by creating a folder in which we will save our Notebooks. Go into the "Workspace" section, which is where such files are kept together. Within your user's workspace create a folder called "Demand forecast".

 

In that new folder create a first Notebook as shown in the next screencam. Rename it to "Demand forecast". And add a short header in Markdown at the top. Markdown is a common way to add comments and context to the code in a Notebook. Adding "#" character at the beginning of a line formats the text as top-level heading. Two "#" characters make it a second-level heading, and so on. Without any "#" character the following text is formatted just normally as plain text. 

To add the Markdown, you need to change the cell's language selector to "Markdown" as shown in the screencam. Enter your text. When done, click outside the cell and the formatting kicks in.

 

Since the cells can also execute SQL code, add the most recent SQL statement from the SQL Editor.

SELECT
  COUNTRYOFRESIDENCE,
  SUM(OVERNIGHTSTAYS) AS total_overnightstays
FROM
  workspace.default.overnightstays
GROUP BY
  COUNTRYOFRESIDENCE
ORDER BY
  total_overnightstays DESC

 

The screencam shows how a new cell can be added to the Notebook, by hovering with the mouse at the bottom of the cell above. Select "Code" as cell type. Change the cell's language selector to "SQL", paste the code and run it with the blue play button. You will see the same result as before in the "SQL Editor".

 

Let's switch to Python for the data exploration so that you have tried all the options. Create a new Code cell, its language selector might already be on "Python" by default. Begin by loading the data into a PySpark DataFrame using the table's fully qualified path.

overnightstays_sdf = spark.read.table("workspace.default.overnightstays")

 

Aggregate the data by month and look at the results. The display command initially shows the data as table, but it also comes with a Graphical User interface to quickly create a plot. Follow the steps in the screencam to create a line chart, to see how the numbers have evolved over time. There is a clear pattern, that especially in July and August the numbers are at their highest.

import pyspark.sql.functions as F
display(overnightstays_sdf.groupBy("month").agg(F.sum("overnightstays").alias("overnightstays")))

 

Now explore, whether we can visually get a feel for an overall trend in the data, whether the numbers tend to go up or down over time. Have the Assistant do the work of writing the code with this request:

Create a new DataFrame that has the year in a new column. aggregate by year and show the result in a plotly chart

Plotly is a very common Python charting library. And indeed, when looking at the yearly totals, the numbers are increasing for the years.  The year 2025 is not meaningful yet in this chart as the dataset only contains January to May for that year.

 

Create a forecast with SAP Databricks

During the above data exploration we saw that the data has a trend (numbers are increasing over time) and some seasonality (ie numbers are largest in the summer). Let's train a Machine Learning that picks up on such patterns and can estimate future values. The Notebook created in this section can also be downloaded from the repository.

In case you are unsure about how to implement the following 4 code blocks, then this screencam will guide you along. It shows in a quick scroll through what the output should look like.

 

Read the historic data again into a PySpark DataFrame.

overnightstays_sdf = spark.read.table("workspace.default.overnightstays")

 

Since we want to create a monthly forecast on the total values, aggregate the history by month. Since we are working with the PySpark DataFrame, the built-in Spark engine is doing the work.

import pyspark.sql.functions as F
overnightstaysmonthly_sdf = overnightstays_sdf.groupBy("month").agg(F.sum("overnightstays").alias("overnightstays"))
display(overnightstaysmonthly_sdf)

 

The data needs to be prepared further, so that the Python package called Prophet can train a time-series model on it.

# Convert Spark DataFrame to Pandas DataFrame (the time series algorithm requires a Pandas DataFrame)
overnightstaysmonthly_df = overnightstaysmonthly_sdf.toPandas()

# Sort the DataFrame by date
overnightstaysmonthly_df = overnightstaysmonthly_df.sort_values('month')

# Rename the columns, as required by the time-series algoritm Prophet
overnightstaysmonthly_df = overnightstaysmonthly_df.rename(columns={'month': 'ds', 'overnightstays': 'y'})

 

We want to use the Prophet package for the forecast, which still needs to be installed. Here we install it directly from the Notebook. However, in the "Good to know" section below you see a more elegant way of using additional Python package, by creating your own customised Base environment.

pip install prophet==1.1.7

 

Everything is now in place to finally train the time-series model. The following block of code contains multiple steps. It is useful to run these steps together under the "with mlflow.start_run() section as this allows to log information about the training run in SAP Databricks.  The following code:

  • Trains the time series model
  • Creates a DataFrame with the future 12 months that are to be forecasted
  • Creates a forecast for the known past and the future 12 months
  • Calculates  and logs the model's accuracy on the known history
  • Plots and logs the known history against the predicted values
  • Logs the number of records that were used during training

Yes, in a real project this code would be even more elaborate. For example you may want to try different model configurations to get even better forecast accuracy. And the accuracy should ideally be calculated on a hold-out sample. Currently the code uses the same data for training as well as for checking the model's accuracy. The accuracy should really be calculated on data the model has never seen before. 

HINT: In case the following code gives the error "MLflow not available", please check in the Environment settings on the right, that the "Environment version" is set to 2. These environments are explained a bit further down in the "Good to know" section further below. For some people it defaults to version 1 (which doesn't include the mlflow library), for others it defaults to the required version 2.

import pandas as pd
from prophet import Prophet
from sklearn.metrics import mean_absolute_percentage_error
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import mlflow, mlflow.tracking._model_registry.utils

mlflow.tracking._model_registry.utils._get_registry_uri_from_spark_session = lambda: "databricks-uc"

with mlflow.start_run():

    # Initialize the Prophet model
    model = Prophet()

    # Fit the model
    model.fit(overnightstaysmonthly_df)

    # Create a DataFrame that contains all dates for which a prediction is required, the future 12 months but also the known past for comparison
    datestopredict_df = model.make_future_dataframe(periods=12, freq='MS')

    # Forecast the future and known past
    forecast_df = model.predict(datestopredict_df)

    # Plot the predictions together with known past
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
    ax.plot(forecast_df['ds'], forecast_df['yhat'], label='Forecast', color='red')
    ax.plot(overnightstaysmonthly_df['ds'], overnightstaysmonthly_df['y'], label='Historical Data')
    ax.fill_between(forecast_df['ds'], forecast_df['yhat_lower'], forecast_df['yhat_upper'], color='red', alpha=0.3)
    ax.set_title('Demand forecast')
    ax.set_xlabel('Month')
    ax.set_ylabel('Total Overnightstays')
    ax.legend()
    ax.grid(True)
    plt.show()

    # Calculate and log model accuracy, here MAPE on training data
    overnightstaysmonthly_df[["ds"]] = overnightstaysmonthly_df[["ds"]].apply(pd.to_datetime)
    anctualsandpredicted_df = overnightstaysmonthly_df[['ds', 'y']].merge(forecast_df[['ds', 'yhat']], on='ds', how='inner', suffixes=('_left', '_right'))
    prophet_mape = mean_absolute_percentage_error(anctualsandpredicted_df['y'], anctualsandpredicted_df['yhat'])
    mlflow.log_metric("mape", prophet_mape)

    # Log the chart in the Unity Catalog / Experiment
    mlflow.log_figure(fig, "Forecast.png") 

    # Log the size of the training dataset
    mlflow.log_metric("rowcount_training", overnightstaysmonthly_df.shape[0])

 

Run the above code and we see our prediction!

 

To persist the forecast, save it as DeltaTable. From here the data can be made available to SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud. That part is outside the scope of this tutorial, please check the documentation.

forecast_sdf = spark.createDataFrame(forecast_df)
forecast_sdf.write.mode("overwrite").saveAsTable("workspace.default.overnightstays_forecast")

 

The forecast is saved as DeltaTable, that means you can see it in the Catalog!

 

The information that was logged during the training is now available in the Experiments section. The model's MAPE (Median Absolute Percentage Error) is at 1.4%, 41 records were used during training and we can see the chart that compares actuals to predictions. Especially when trying out different settings for the Machine Learning algorithm, this tracking becomes very useful, for instance to select which configuration to use for the prediction.

 

Schedule

Everything we need for our demand forecast is implemented and we can run it manually. That means we are also good to have it automated with a schedule. Straight from the notebook you can define the scheduling logic, ie the recurring interval and whether you want any notifications. The notebooks can also be triggered through APIs if you prefer.

 

Good to know

A few things that might be good to know.

 

Base file

In the above code the Python package Prophet is installed directly from within a Notebook. That's ok, but not ideal for ongoing use. If you were repeatedly re-running all cells from the Notebook, then Python will try to re-install the package every time. It's generally better to centrally specify the packages you know you will be using long term. This also ensures consistency across projects and developers. In SAP Databricks you can specify reusable / shareable lists of Python packages that are to be installed through Base environments.

Create a Base environment by creating a file called base_env_prophet.yaml with this content:

dependencies:
  - prophet==1.1.7

 

With this base file in place, you can

  • Step 1: Remove the pip install command from the "020 Demand forecast" Notebook

 

  • Step 2: Specify that the Notebook will use the base file instead, to determine which packages to install. Here you can also select the Environment version. These are documented here.

 

To test out that the Package is correctly installed through the base file, clear the environment as shown in the screencam and run the Python code in the cells.

 

Lineage & Table usage insights

Now that the table "overnightstays" has been used a few times, check out the lineage, which shows where the table is used and the statistics on how heavily that table is used. 

 

Visuals

From the distance most Notebooks look very much alike at first glance. I heard some great feedback that some visual / image on top of the notebook would help to differentiate. In the repository you find a few examples, in case you would like to use those to distinguish between Data Exploration, AI/ML Sandboxing and AI/ML Deployment.

Upload any images that you want to use into the Workspace. To keep things tidy I am creating a separate folder for them.

 

These images can then be shown in a Markup cell.

 

Summary

SAP Databricks is adding a dedicated Data Science environment to the SAP landscape. After this hands-on experience you hopefully have a first feel for how a Data Scientist can enrich the data in SAP Business Data Cloud with Machine Learning.

For your own projects, you will want to check out the documentation:

  • SAP Databricks documentation by SAP
  • SAP Databricks documentation by Databricks

 

I hope you enjoyed getting hands-on with SAP Databricks!

entry.title: Why we created Open Resource Discovery
entry.content:
What is Open Resource Discovery?

Open Resource Discovery (ORD) is a protocol for application / service metadata publishing and discovery. It can be used as a foundation for metadata catalogs / marketplaces and runtime introspection of system landscape resources. For more information, have a look at the ORD Introduction.

Building a static API & Event Catalog

The origin of ORD was as a publishing channel to SAP Business Accelerator Hub - formerly known as SAP API Hub - the centralized catalog for the public APIs and events offered by SAP products and SAP‚Äôs partners.

SAP aspires to offer one central place where developers can browse and explore existing APIs and get the API contracts as opposed to a proliferation of disconnected API portals and catalogs per product. From the beginning, we needed to support multiple protocols like OData, plain REST and SOAP. Early in this project, we established the use of open industry standards, most notably OpenAPI as the common denominator to describe all REST-based APIs (incl. OData).

When putting many different protocols and metadata description formats into one catalog, it quickly becomes obvious that the catalog needs some reliably consistent information across them:

  • Description: Titles, (short) descriptions, links, tags, etc.
  • Lifecycle: Version, lifecycle status and timelines (beta, active, deprecated), successors for deprecated, changelog, etc.
  • Taxonomy: Assignment to vendors, products, industry taxonomy, etc.
  • Grouping: Which resources belong together, can be discovered together

The second challenge was to provide an easy, automated way to publish the API & Event metadata, including the shared information listed above.

In 2018-2019, this led to the first drafts of the ORD protocol, driven by the Business Accelerator Hub team. The idea was to define a Service Provider Interface (SPI) enabling applications to expose their metadata by describing themselves, as an application is the only reliable source of information about itself. ORD is entirely complementary to the metadata industry standards we were already using; it merely provides a discovery wrapper around them and adds some common shared information, taxonomy, and relationships to build a single catalog from many individual sources.

With the ORD API implemented, an application can now register itself on Business Accelerator Hub and the metadata can be crawled and published without manual intervention, thus streamlining the publishing process.

Understanding Customer System Landscapes (Runtime Introspection)

In 2020, the Open Resource Discovery specification moved ownership to SAP‚Äôs Cross-Product Alignment (CPA) team. We quickly realized the potential in this idea, also beyond publishing static metadata to Business Accelerator Hub.

In the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), we needed a better understanding of the runtime (customer) system landscapes, including API and event resources. Since many of SAP‚Äôs larger solutions are highly customizable and extensible, the challenge is that each tenant can be different: some APIs may not be activated, some may have field extensions, some may have been added by the customer. Since the metadata in Business Accelerator Hub is static, it can only document a generic baseline of what a customer could look like. To find out what has changed since the snapshot taken in Business Accelerator Hub, it has become necessary to inspect the metadata of the systems at runtime.

This runtime metadata can be very useful ‚Äì for example, when creating side-by-side extensions in BTP or SAP Build, the developers benefit from knowing the actual state of interfaces, so they can find them more quickly and safely build against them

We realized that the same protocol and interfaces can be used to do both: describe the static baseline metadata and its current state. Therefore, we generalized the ORD specification to work for both static and runtime metadata discovery and integrate it with the Unified Customer Landscape (UCL).

When generalizing the ORD standard, we defined some design goals ‚Äì one of which was that the standard should work not only for SAP but be more general-purpose, so that it can be adopted and used by other companies once we open-sourced it. After verifying that ORD works well in SAP production environments, we released v1.0 to general availability in 2021.

Support Adoption and Validation with Tooling

Developers and integrations rely on machine-readable, well documented API interfaces. To improve the overall experience, we need to ensure that we have 1) wide coverage of metadata existing resources and 2) decent quality, so that API metadata is useful, consistent, and reliable for human developers and machines alike.

To scale this across a large company like SAP, it‚Äôs essential to not only provide guidelines and specs ‚Äì we also need to make it easy to adopt the metadata approach and have a quick validation / feedback loop.

For the ease of adoption, the obvious solution is to build ORD support right into the frameworks, like the ABAP Platform or the CAP Framework and provide a generic provider server to easily provide static metadata.

The quality and validation aspect turned out to be a big topic of its own ‚Äì we invested in creating a metadata validator that can not only validate ORD, but also the most important metadata formats we transport along inside of it. Quality is also a gradual and moving goal, so we created a concept of ‚Äúpolicy levels‚Äù in which we distinguish between various degrees or goals of quality ‚Äì and can validate which level the published content has achieved.

To increase the quality of the metadata, we realized that we need to come to the validation step early in the process (‚Äúshift left‚Äù), so we don‚Äôt identify issues too late, in the worst case not before publishing. Validation ideally happens in the CI/CD of the local application development. The central publishing targets then act as quality gates to ensure at least a baseline for quality. Therefore, we made sure that our validation runs in the central quality gates and at the same time made it easy for product teams to run the same validations locally.

By continuously validating already published metadata according to old and new rules, we have a data-driven approach to identify where we need to increase quality and which validation rules are realistic to enforce. With this loop, we were already able to improve the metadata and documentation quality of SAP software and can grow it continuously.

Integrating Data Products into ORD

In 2022-2023, when we started the work on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), the Data Mesh and Data Product topic become very relevant to us as a company. We quickly realized the potential of reusing the ORD specification and the infrastructure for metadata discovery, validation, and cataloging. Even better, by integrating data products into ORD, we were able to ensure that data products are not a silo for data scientists but are interconnected with the existing, more developer-oriented concepts of APIs and Event

We enabled the description of Data Products in ORD to make them describable and discoverable just like other resources. For Data Products, some specialized API protocols like Delta Sharing became relevant to add. At this stage, we also had to extend ORD to describe integration dependencies to indicate input ports (potential data lineage) and we further invested into connecting all ORD concepts with business and domain concepts, like Business Objects (Entity Types). For more background, have a look at the blog post: The Metadata behind SAP Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud.

We have now started to connect APIs, Events, and Data Products to business processes, as this connects the concepts of various personas (developers, data scientists, business experts). By interlinking the concepts, we help discovery, search and make it easier to understand what belongs together.

Extend with AI and Knowledge Graph

We are currently seeing a rise in specialized AI agent protocols like MCP and A2A. With this comes a need to build registries / catalogs so consumers or agents can discover them. From the ORD perspective, agent or tools are just a special  type of API protocol we could put in the same API catalog - just like Delta Sharing was a new API Protocol geared towards Data Products.

Current efforts on MCP and A2A seem to solve the discovery problem for a single protocol in isolation. However, we see value in having a combined catalog that can include both MCP and A2A ‚Äì and it is likely there will be more agent protocols to follow.

AI agents will benefit from knowledge graphs for further grounding, for helping to avoid AI hallucinations, for storing knowledge explicitly, to reduce the cost and compute of agentic planning, and to provide explain-ability of reasoning. Building an MCP API / proxy around every existing API is costly, so we see potential in bringing in the huge, existing ecosystem of APIs, Events, and Data Products into knowledge graphs. We also see value in having AI to assist with understanding often very complex, customized system landscapes and what they offer, how they can be integrated, and extended.

Establishing ORD as a Linux Foundation Standard

In 2023, ORD was released as an SAP open-source standard, accessible for industry-wide adoption. In 2025 we changed ORD's ownership model, contributing it to the Linux Foundation via the publicly funded ApeiroRA / IPCEI-CIS program. With this we ensure vendor-neutral governance and long-term independence from SAP. The standard is now open to contributions and ownership of other companies as well. Thus, ORD has laid the foundation to potentially become an accepted industry standard. ORD received the 2025 API award in the category ‚ÄúBest in API standards and specification‚Äù.

Our Vision

We believe that we have created something special with ORD: We are not aware of any stable, open-source standard that can handle the metadata discovery of applications / services across different protocols and types of resources, tailored to the requirements of various personas and products. There are a few projects with similar goals ‚Äì some redundant, some complementary ‚Äì as ORD. A detailed comparison would require at least one more blog post, which may come at a different time.

Many years of SAP experience across multiple products, use cases, and stakeholders went into the standard. With ORD, it‚Äôs possible to break up metadata silos and create a well-connected metadata graph of the technical resources in your IT landscape.

We believe that a good metadata integration architecture is an important pillar to achieve transparency in a well-integrated IT landscape and benefits developers, applications and AI alike.

If you have questions, feedback, or interest in collaboration, feel free to create a GitHub issue or reach out to Simon Heimler directly. We are looking forward to collaborating with other companies on the future of ORD. Collaboration with the Technical Steering Committee is very welcome.

entry.title: AI-Powered Operational Excellence in Cloud ALM's Real User Monitoring
entry.content:
Introduction

In this blog we would discuss and get to know how the available Artificial Intelligence use cases can be activated and used in a customers landscape. There are various AI capability planned in SAP Cloud ALM, be it for Implementation or Operations space.

At present, specific to operations, Change point detection in Real User Monitoring is an AI feature a customer could leverage free of cost. In this blog we would discuss about "Change point detection in Real User Monitoring".

To Understand more about Real User Monitoring(RUM) please refer to https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/operations/expert-portal/real-user-monitoring.html?anchorId=section

Cloud ALM Expert Portal for operations is a one stop solution for all your Operations related asks in Cloud ALM. https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/operations/expert-portal.html

Change Point detection in Real User Monitoring(RUM)

Expert Portal for Operation defines Real User Monitoring as:

The purpose of Real User Monitoring is to provide transparency about the usage (executions) and the performance (response times) of user interactions. It supports the monitoring request executions from different platforms with a unified user experience using a common look-and-feel and handling pattern.

The basic concept is to get all user interactions and the relevant server requests which are the correlated in the Real User Monitoring application. Request executions are rated not based on fixed thresholds but on historical values.

Real User Monitoring shall help IT users and Business users to understand how often applications are executed and what is the response times for the end-users.

What is Change Point detection:

A change point for a request name signifies a notable performance shift compared to the recent past, lasting for a brief period (not just single executions). Such a change point might suggest an event that warrants closer examination.

How to activate Change Point Detection.

  1. Select Real User Monitoring card available under Operations area of SAP Cloud ALM. If you do not see RUM card, please make sure to have required authorization added to your user.

2. Make sure that data collection for the supported system is enabled.

3. Click on the system for which you want to activate ‚ÄúChange Point Detection‚Äú.

4.Activate the Change point Detection by enabling the toggle button and click on Save.
